result.title: Fegla Qualifications 2016 Tutorial
result.content:
First of all we like to thank:

Chief Judge: Coach Mohamed Abdel-Wahab (fegla).

Authors : Hossam Yossef (hoa_2alk_fain), Abdullah Bahosain(AU.Bahosain), Hasan Alhamsh(2Nodes).

Problem texts : Nicole Hosh, Hossameldin Omar(hossameldeenfci), Hossam Yossef(hoa_2alk_fain).

Solutions : Hossam Yossef(hoa_2alk_fain), Hasan Alhamsh(2Nodes), Abdullah Bahosain(AU.Bahosain), Noureldin Yousry(Noureldin), Omar Hashim(OmarHashim).

Testers : Mohamed Osama El-Tohamy(mc_mosa), Mohamed Yasser(Mohammad_Yasser), Hasan Alhamsh(2Nodes), Hossameldin Omar(hossameldeenfci), Ahmed Hamed(ahmedhamed), Ahmed Ossama(TsunamiNextYear), Abdullah Bahosain(AU.Bahosain), Noureldin Yousry(Noureldin), Samer Raed(SaMer), Omar Hashim(OmarHashim), Amr Mahmoud(AmrMahmoud)

A. Balalance

Author: Hossam Youssef(hoa_2alk_fain) — Text: Hossameldin Omar(hossameldeenfci) — Solution: Omar Hashim(OmarHashim)

If the length of the string is odd, the answer is -1, otherwise there will always be a way.

From the definition of a balanced string, either the right most bracket closes the left most bracket, or the string can be split into two balanced substrings. So we will try both and minimize the cost, we will use dp[l][r] : the minimum cost to make the range a balanced string, then the answer is dp[1][n] where n is the length of the string.

B. Qualifications

Author: Hossam Youssef(hoa_2alk_fain) — Text: Hossam Youssef(hoa_2alk_fain) — Solution: Hasan Alhamsh(2Nodes).

So here we have the score from previous contests, and one more contest will be held, top m participants will get scores, and we want to know the highest overall place, and lowest overall place mortadella can have after this contest.

Calculating the worst place is the easier part, we first sort the array b in decreasing order, if m=n, we give mortadella the lowest b value, then we sort the other participants first by decreasing score, and in case of a tie, we sort by names in lexicographical order, then we use two pointers, loop on participants from worst to best, and a pointer to loop on b values from highest to lowest , if giving the current b value to the current participant will make him have a better place than mortadella, then we give it to him.

Now to calculate the best place. If m>0, we give mortadella the highest b value. We will sort participants and values b the same way again. Now some participants have higher place than mortadella even without giving them any b values, we give these participants highest availabe b values to get rid of such big values, then for the remaining b values we loop on the worst participants from best to worst and for each one of them,if giving him the smallest value will make him have a higher place than mortadella, we give him the highest available value, otherwise we give him the highest value that would give him a place worse than motradella's, this can be done using multiset or map.

C. Unit Cube

Author: Hossam Youssef(hoa_2alk_fain) — Text: Hossameldin Omar(hossameldeenfci) — Solution: Hossam Youssef(hoa_2alk_fain).

Suppose we have a cuboid of dimensions a,b,c , where c>1 , and we make a cut such that we get two cuboids of dimensions a,b,1 and a,b,c-1 , now its obvious that the second cuboid is going to require number of cuts greater than or equal to the first cuboid , while we are cutting the bigger cuboid we will put the smaller one next to it and cut it at the same time, so after this cut the answer will be 1 + minimum number of cuts to make the bigger resulting cuboid into pieces.

After each cut we will work on the bigger cuboid so we want it to be as small as possible, so we always cut it in half, which gives us the 3-liner code

   ans = 0;
   while(a>1)++ans, a = ceil(a/2)
   while(b>1)++ans, b = ceil(b/2)
   while(c>1)++ans, c = ceil(c/2)

D. Queue

Author: Hossam Youssef(hoa_2alk_fain) — Text: Hossameldin Omar(hossameldeenfci) — Solution: Hossam Youssef(hoa_2alk_fain).

Since we have n<=8 we can try every possible arrangement, and choose the one with minimum hits, this can be done using function next_permutation.

E. Lock Screen

Author: Abdullah Bahosain(AU.Bahosain) — Text: Nicole Hosh — Solution: Abdullah Bahosain(AU.Bahosain)

If between any two consecutive keys both the x and y values change, then this is not horizontal nor vertical segment, so if such two consecutive keys exist then the password is strong.

F. Game

Author: Hasan Alhamsh(2Nodes) — Text: Nicole Hosh — Solution: Hasan Alhamsh(2Nodes)

An error is when a node have the value 1 but its parent has value 0, coach Fegla wants to minimize this, so he always puts the value 1 as a child of a parent of value 1 if its possible, otherwise he makes an error, while Hanaa wants to maximize the number of errors, so she tries to give the value 0 a parent with value 1 while she can to prevent the coach from making his goal, if you draw a heap of small height you will see that number of errors at height 0 and 1 is 0, and at height h >= 2 is 2h - 2 so at h < 2, ans = 0, otherwise ans = 2h - 1 - 1

G. Balaloons

Author: Hossam Youssef(hoa_2alk_fain) — Text: Nicole Hosh — Solution: Hasan Alhamsh(2Nodes)

We can loop on the balloons and keep the current bullet speed with us, if the speed is greater than 0, the balloon will be hit, and after each iteration we minus D from currect speed, this gives complexity O(N), but it can also be solved in O(1)

H. Passwords

Author: Hossam Youssef(hoa_2alk_fain) — Text: Nicole Hosh — Solution: Hossam Youssef(hoa_2alk_fain)

Loop on the string and count occurence of each character, then for each character that occured atleast once we add it into a list, then we sort the list first by increasing number of occurence, and in case of a tie, we sort by lexicographical order of the letter, and then print the median.

I. Keys

Author: Hossam Youssef(hoa_2alk_fain) — Text: Nicole Hosh — Solution: Hossam Youssef(hoa_2alk_fain)

Calculate the value of each key, if it's bigger than or equal k, then print it.

J. Mall Alone

Author: Hossam Youssef(hoa_2alk_fain) — Text: Hossameldin Omar(hossameldeenfci) — Solution: Noureldin Yousry(Noureldin)

First we will run bfs from every coin, and one more bfs from starting position, we can then try all c combinations of coins from all of the coins, and then choose the order of picking them using next_permutation, inside next_permutation we can use an O(c) loop to check the cost of picking the coins in this order and then going to the exit (if it's possible), and minimize the answer.

let k be the total number of coins in the mall, then we can calculate the complexity.
